1.71.text: THERESA MAY: A little over six months ago, the British people voted for change.

7.48.text:
They voted to shape a brighter future for
our country.

11.34.text: They voted to leave the European Union and embrace the world.

16.57.text: And they did so with their eyes open: accepting that the road ahead will be uncertain at times,

23.75.text: but believing that it leads towards a brighter future for their children - and their grandchildren too.

30.44.text: And it is the job of this Government to deliver it. That means more than negotiating our new

36.75.text:
relationship with the EU. It means taking
the opportunity of this great moment of national

43.45.text: change to step back and ask ourselves what kind of country we want to be.

51.80.text: My answer is clear. I want this United Kingdom to emerge from this period of change stronger,

59.69.text: fairer, more united and more outward-looking than ever before. I want us to be a secure,

68.33.text:
prosperous, tolerant country - a magnet for
international talent and a home to the pioneers

74.90.text: and innovators who will shape the world ahead. I want us to be a truly Global Britain – the

81.84.text:
best friend and neighbour to our European
partners, but a country that reaches beyond

87.47.text:
the borders of Europe too. A country that
gets out into the world to build relationships

93.47.text: with old friends and new allies alike.

97.79.text: I want Britain to be what we have the potential, talent and ambition to be. A great, global

104.55.text:
trading nation that is respected around the
world and strong, confident and united at home.

114.20.text:
That is why this Government has a Plan for
Britain. One that gets us the right deal abroad

121.68.text:
but also ensures we get a better deal for
ordinary working people at home.

126.98.text:
It’s why that plan sets out how we will
use this moment of change to build a stronger

133.14.text:
economy and a fairer society by embracing
genuine economic and social reform.

140.28.text:
Why our new Modern Industrial Strategy is
being developed, to ensure every nation and

145.28.text: area of the United Kingdom can make the most of the opportunities ahead. Why we will go

151.32.text: further to reform our schools to ensure every child has the knowledge and the skills they

156.36.text:
need to thrive in post-Brexit Britain. Why
as we continue to bring the deficit down,

163.91.text: we will take a balanced approach by investing in our economic infrastructure - because it

169.07.text:
can transform the growth potential of our
economy, and improve the quality of people’s

174.25.text:
lives across the whole country.
It’s why we will put the preservation of

179.72.text: our precious Union at the heart of everything we do. Because it is only by coming together

186.12.text: as one great union of nations and people that we can make the most of the opportunities

191.72.text: ahead. The result of the referendum was not a decision

197.48.text:
to turn inward and retreat from the world.
Because Britain’s history and culture is

203.31.text:
profoundly internationalist.
We are a European country – and proud of

208.36.text:
our shared European heritage – but we are
also a country that has always looked beyond

214.12.text:
Europe to the wider world. That is why we
are one of the most racially diverse countries

220.29.text: in Europe, one of the most multicultural members of the European Union, and why – whether

226.12.text: we are talking about India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, America, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, countries

232.51.text:
in Africa or those that are closer to home
in Europe – so many of us have close friends

237.97.text:
and relatives from across the world.
Instinctively, we want to travel to, study

244.09.text:
in, trade with countries not just in Europe
but beyond the borders of our continent. Even

250.68.text:
now as we prepare to leave the EU, we are
planning for the next biennial Commonwealth

256.13.text:
Heads of Government meeting in 2018 – a
reminder of our unique and proud global relationships.

263.87.text:
And it is important to recognise this fact.
June the 23rd was not the moment Britain chose

272.03.text: to step back from the world. It was the moment we chose to build a truly Global Britain.

279.08.text:
I know that this – and the other reasons
Britain took such a decision – is not always

284.24.text: well understood among our friends and allies in Europe. And I know many fear that this

289.73.text: might herald the beginning of a greater unravelling of the EU.

294.92.text:
But let me be clear: I do not want that to
happen. It would not be in the best interests

301.28.text:
of Britain. It remains overwhelmingly and
compellingly in Britain’s national interest

307.34.text: that the EU should succeed. And that is why I hope in the months and years ahead we will

313.65.text:
all reflect on the lessons of Britain’s
decision to leave.

318.26.text:
So let me take this opportunity to set out
the reasons for our decision and to address

323.51.text:
the people of Europe directly.
It’s not simply because our history and

329.23.text: culture is profoundly internationalist, important though that is. Many in Britain have always

336.51.text:
felt that the United Kingdom’s place in
the European Union came at the expense of

341.59.text:
our global ties, and of a bolder embrace of
free trade with the wider world.

346.92.text:
There are other important reasons too.
Our political traditions are different. Unlike

353.89.text: other European countries, we have no written constitution, but the principle of Parliamentary

358.99.text:
Sovereignty is the basis of our unwritten
constitutional settlement. We have only a

364.29.text: recent history of devolved governance – though it has rapidly embedded itself - and we have

369.64.text:
little history of coalition government. The
public expect to be able to hold their governments

376.00.text:
to account very directly, and as a result
supranational institutions as strong as those

383.28.text: created by the European Union sit very uneasily in relation to our political history and way

389.21.text: of life. And, while I know Britain might at times have

393.50.text: been seen as an awkward member state, the European Union has struggled to deal with

398.78.text:
the diversity of its member countries and
their interests. It bends towards uniformity,

405.72.text:
not flexibility. David Cameron’s negotiation
was a valiant final attempt to make it work

412.60.text:
for Britain - and I want to thank all those
elsewhere in Europe who helped him reach an

418.64.text: agreement - but the blunt truth, as we know, is that there was not enough flexibility on

424.49.text: many important matters for a majority of British voters.

428.45.text: Now I do not believe that these things apply uniquely to Britain. Britain is not the only

434.51.text: member state where there is a strong attachment to accountable and democratic government,

438.99.text:
such a strong internationalist mindset, or
a belief that diversity within Europe should

443.30.text:
be celebrated. And so I believe there is a
lesson in Brexit not just for Britain but,

448.54.text:
if it wants to succeed, for the EU itself.
Because our continent’s great strength has

455.11.text:
always been its diversity. And there are two
ways of dealing with different interests.

461.89.text: You can respond by trying to hold things together by force, tightening a vice-like grip that

466.40.text:
ends up crushing into tiny pieces the very
things you want to protect. Or you can respect

472.00.text:
difference, cherish it even, and reform the
EU so that it deals better with the wonderful

477.40.text:
diversity of its member states.
So to our friends across Europe, let me say

483.17.text: this. Our vote to leave the European Union was no

486.62.text: rejection of the values we share. The decision to leave the EU represents no desire to become

492.99.text: more distant to you, our friends and neighbours.  It was no attempt to do harm to the EU itself

499.92.text:
or to any of its remaining member states.
We do not want to turn the clock back to the

506.06.text: days when Europe was less peaceful, less secure and less able to trade freely. It was a vote

512.00.text:
to restore, as we see it, our parliamentary
democracy, national self-determination, and

518.76.text: to become even more global and internationalist in action and in spirit.

525.26.text:
We will continue to be reliable partners,
willing allies and close friends. We want

531.39.text: to buy your goods and services, sell you ours, trade with you as freely as possible, and

536.75.text:
work with one another to make sure we are
all safer, more secure and more prosperous

542.21.text: through continued friendship. You will still be welcome in this country

546.00.text:
as we hope our citizens will be welcome in
yours. At a time when together we face a serious

552.00.text:
threat from our enemies, Britain’s unique
intelligence capabilities will continue to

557.40.text: help to keep people in Europe safe from terrorism. And at a time when there is growing concern

563.64.text: about European security, Britain’s servicemen and women, based in European countries including

569.95.text:
Estonia, Poland and Romania, will continue
to do their duty.

575.77.text:
We are leaving the European Union, but we
are not leaving Europe.

581.19.text: And that is why we seek a new and equal partnership – between an independent, self-governing,

587.77.text:
Global Britain and our friends and allies
in the EU.

592.58.text: Not partial membership of the European Union, associate membership of the European Union,

598.34.text:
or anything that leaves us half-in, half-out.
We do not seek to adopt a model already enjoyed

605.28.text:
by other countries. We do not seek to hold
on to bits of membership as we leave.

611.40.text: No, the United Kingdom is leaving the European Union. And my job is to get the right deal

617.79.text:
for Britain as we do.
So today I want to outline our objectives

625.13.text: for the negotiation ahead. 12 objectives that amount to one big goal: a new, positive and

633.74.text: constructive partnership between Britain and the European Union.

637.88.text: And as we negotiate that partnership, we will be driven by some simple principles: we will

645.66.text:
provide as much certainty and clarity as we
can at every stage. And we will take this

651.10.text: opportunity to make Britain stronger, to make Britain fairer, and to build a more Global

656.99.text: Britain too. The first objective is crucial. We will provide

664.02.text:
certainty wherever we can.
We are about to enter a negotiation. That

670.12.text: means there will be give and take. There will have to be compromises. It will require imagination

676.24.text: on both sides. And not everybody will be able to know everything at every stage.

683.10.text: But I recognise how important it is to provide business, the public sector, and everybody

689.13.text: with as much certainty as possible as we move through the process.

694.48.text: So where we can offer that certainty, we will do so.

699.15.text:
That is why last year we acted quickly to
give clarity about farm payments and university

704.66.text: funding. And it is why, as we repeal the European Communities

708.94.text:
Act, we will convert the “acquis” – the
body of existing EU law – into British law.

715.62.text: This will give the country maximum certainty as we leave the EU. The same rules and laws

721.33.text:
will apply on the day after Brexit as they
did before. And it will be for the British

727.87.text: Parliament to decide on any changes to that law after full scrutiny and proper Parliamentary

734.24.text: debate. And when it comes to Parliament, there is

738.08.text: one other way in which I would like to provide certainty. I can confirm today that the Government

743.85.text: will put the final deal that is agreed between the UK and the EU to a vote in both Houses

749.46.text:
of Parliament, before it comes into force.
Our second guiding principle is to build a

757.91.text: stronger Britain. That means taking control of our own affairs,

763.36.text: as those who voted in their millions to leave the European Union demanded we must.

768.34.text: So we will take back control of our laws and bring an end to the jurisdiction of the European

773.11.text: Court of Justice in Britain. Leaving the European Union will mean that

777.81.text: our laws will be made in Westminster, Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast. And those laws will be

783.72.text: interpreted by judges not in Luxembourg but in courts across this country.

789.56.text: Because we will not have truly left the European Union if we are not in control of our own

794.67.text: laws. A stronger Britain demands that we do something

799.36.text: else - strengthen the precious union between the four nations of the United Kingdom.

805.52.text: At this momentous time, it is more important than ever that we face the future together,

812.74.text:
united by what makes us strong: the bonds
that unite us as a people, and our shared

818.13.text: interest in the UK being an open, successful trading nation in the future.

823.95.text:
And I hope that same spirit of unity will
apply in Northern Ireland in particular over

829.85.text: the coming months in the Assembly elections, and the main parties there will work together

834.99.text: to re-establish a partnership government as soon as possible.

839.86.text: Foreign affairs are of course the responsibility of the UK Government, and in dealing with

844.56.text:
them we act in the interests of all parts
of the United Kingdom. As Prime Minister,

850.03.text:
I take that responsibility seriously.
I have also been determined from the start

856.40.text: that the devolved administrations should be fully engaged in this process.

861.53.text: That is why the Government has set up a Joint Ministerial Committee on EU Negotiations,

866.97.text: so ministers from each of the UK’s devolved administrations can contribute to the process

871.88.text: of planning for our departure from the European Union.

875.89.text:
We have already received a paper from the
Scottish Government, and look forward to receiving

880.25.text: a paper from the Welsh Government shortly. Both papers will be considered as part of

885.44.text:
this important process. We won’t agree on
everything, but I look forward to working

891.73.text:
with the administrations in Scotland, Wales
and Northern Ireland to deliver a Brexit that

896.95.text:
works for the whole of the United Kingdom.
Part of that will mean working very carefully

903.82.text:
to ensure that – as powers are repatriated
from Brussels back to Britain – the right

908.95.text: powers are returned to Westminster, and the right powers are passed to the devolved administrations

914.44.text:
of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
As we do so, our guiding principle must be

920.86.text:
to ensure that - as we leave the European
Union - no new barriers to living and doing

926.20.text:
business within our own Union are created,
That means maintaining the necessary common

932.99.text: standards and frameworks for our own domestic market, empowering the UK as an open, trading

939.01.text:
nation to strike the best trade deals around
the world, and protecting the common resources

944.05.text: of our islands. And as we do this, I should equally be clear

948.32.text: that no decisions currently taken by the devolved administrations will be removed from them.

954.84.text: We cannot forget that, as we leave, the United Kingdom will share a land border with the

960.42.text: EU, and maintaining that Common Travel Area with the Republic of Ireland will be an important

966.79.text:
priority for the UK in the talks ahead.
There has been a Common Travel Area between

972.55.text: the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland for many years. Indeed, it was formed before

977.61.text: either of our two countries were members of the European Union. And the family ties and

982.99.text: bonds of affection that unite our two countries mean that there will always be a special relationship

988.61.text: between us. So we will work to deliver a practical solution

993.20.text: that allows the maintenance of the Common Travel Area with the Republic, while protecting

997.88.text: the integrity of the United Kingdom’s immigration system.

1002.26.text: Nobody wants to return to the borders of the past, so we will make it a priority to deliver

1008.16.text:
a practical solution as soon as we can.
The third principle is to build a fairer Britain.

1017.67.text:
That means ensuring it is fair to everyone
who lives and works in this country.

1022.80.text: And that is why we will ensure we can control immigration to Britain from Europe.

1028.04.text:
We will continue to attract the brightest
and the best to work or study in Britain – indeed

1033.81.text: openness to international talent must remain one of this country’s most distinctive assets

1039.30.text: – but that process must be managed properly so that our immigration system serves the

1044.67.text: national interest. So we will get control of the number of people

1048.80.text: coming to Britain from the EU. Because while controlled immigration can bring

1054.83.text:
great benefits – filling skills shortages,
delivering public services, making British

1060.28.text: businesses the world-beaters they often are – when the numbers get too high, public

1065.94.text:
support for the system falters.
In the last decade or so, we have seen record

1072.19.text:
levels of net migration in Britain, and that
sheer volume has put pressure on public services,

1077.71.text:
like schools, stretched our infrastructure,
especially housing, and put a downward pressure

1082.67.text: on wages for working class people. As Home Secretary for six years, I know that you cannot

1088.59.text:
control immigration overall when there is
free movement to Britain from Europe.

1093.90.text:
Britain is an open and tolerant country. We
will always want immigration, especially high-skilled

1099.72.text: immigration, we will always want immigration from Europe, and we will always welcome individual

1104.73.text:
migrants as friends. But the message from
the public before and during the referendum

1110.56.text: campaign was clear: Brexit must mean control of the number of people who come to Britain

1116.94.text: from Europe. And that is what we will deliver. Fairness demands that we deal with another

1124.11.text:
issue as soon as possible too. We want to
guarantee the rights of EU citizens who are

1130.41.text:
already living in Britain, and the rights
of British nationals in other member states,

1135.34.text: as early as we can.  I have told other EU leaders that we could

1139.76.text:
give people the certainty they want straight
away, and reach such a deal now.

1144.77.text: Many of them favour such an agreement - one or two others do not - but I want everyone

1150.21.text: to know that it remains an important priority for Britain – and for many other member

1155.50.text:
states – to resolve this challenge as soon
as possible. Because it is the right and fair

1161.21.text: thing to do. And a fairer Britain is a country that protects

1167.48.text: and enhances the rights people have at work. That is why, as we translate the body of European

1173.18.text:
law into our domestic regulations, we will
ensure that workers rights are fully protected

1179.03.text: and maintained. Indeed, under my leadership, not only will

1183.75.text: the Government protect the rights of workers’ set out in European legislation, we will build

1188.22.text: on them. Because under this Conservative Government, we will make sure legal protection for workers

1193.80.text: keeps pace with the changing labour market – and that the voices of workers are heard

1198.98.text:
by the boards of publicly-listed companies
for the first time.

1204.85.text:
But the great prize for this country – the
opportunity ahead – is to use this moment

1210.32.text:
to build a truly Global Britain. A country
that reaches out to old friends and new allies.

1217.20.text:
A great, global, trading nation. And one of
the firmest advocates for free trade anywhere

1224.38.text: in the world. That starts with our close friends and neighbours

1228.85.text:
in Europe. So as a priority, we will pursue
a bold and ambitious Free Trade Agreement

1235.38.text: with the European Union. This agreement should allow for the freest

1240.23.text: possible trade in goods and services between Britain and the EU’s member states. It should

1246.45.text: give British companies the maximum freedom to trade with and operate within European

1252.15.text:
markets – and let European businesses do
the same in Britain.

1257.85.text:
But I want to be clear. What I am proposing
cannot mean membership of the EU’s Single

1264.44.text: Market. European leaders have said many times that

1269.71.text: membership means accepting the “four freedoms” of goods, capital, services and people. And

1277.31.text: being out of the EU but a member of the Single Market would mean complying with the EU’s

1283.32.text:
rules and regulations that implement those
freedoms, without having a vote on what those

1288.17.text: rules and regulations are. It would mean accepting a role for the European Court of Justice that

1295.15.text: would see it still having direct legal authority in our country.

1299.84.text:
It would to all intents and purposes mean
not leaving the EU at all.

1307.30.text: And that is why both sides in the referendum campaign made it clear that a vote to leave

1312.42.text:
the EU would be a vote to leave the Single
Market.

1316.94.text: So we do not seek membership of the Single Market. Instead we seek the greatest possible

1323.59.text:
access to it through a new, comprehensive,
bold and ambitious Free Trade Agreement.

1331.17.text: That Agreement may take in elements of current Single Market arrangements in certain areas

1336.14.text:
– on the export of cars and lorries for
example, or the freedom to provide financial

1340.41.text:
services across national borders – as it
makes no sense to start again from scratch

1346.57.text: when Britain and the remaining Member States have adhered to the same rules for so many

1350.44.text: years. But I respect the position taken by European

1355.05.text: leaders who have been clear about their position, just as I am clear about mine. So an important

1361.82.text: part of the new strategic partnership we seek with the EU will be the pursuit of the greatest

1367.43.text:
possible access to the Single Market, on a
fully reciprocal basis, through a comprehensive

1373.25.text: Free Trade Agreement. And because we will no longer be members of

1378.31.text:
the Single Market, we will not be required
to contribute huge sums to the EU budget.

1383.84.text: There may be some specific European programmes in which we might want to participate. If

1389.40.text:
so, and this will be for us to decide, it
is reasonable that we should make an appropriate

1394.27.text:
contribution. But the principle is clear:
the days of Britain making vast contributions

1400.23.text:
to the European Union every year will end.
But it is not just trade with the EU we should

1408.40.text:
be interested in. A Global Britain must be
free to strike trade agreements with countries

1413.96.text:
from outside the European Union too.
Because important though our trade with the

1419.93.text:
EU is and will remain, it is clear that the
UK needs to increase significantly its trade

1426.71.text:
with the fastest growing export markets in
the world.

1431.13.text:
Since joining the EU, trade as a percentage
of GDP has broadly stagnated in the UK. That

1438.04.text:
is why it is time for Britain to get out into
the world and rediscover its role as a great,

1445.31.text: global, trading nation. This is such a priority for me that when I

1450.02.text: became Prime Minister I established, for the first time, a Department for International

1454.87.text: Trade, led by Liam Fox. We want to get out into the wider world, to

1462.78.text:
trade and do business all around the globe.
Countries including China, Brazil, and the

1468.47.text: Gulf States have already expressed their interest in striking trade deals with us. We have started

1473.92.text: discussions on future trade ties with countries like Australia, New Zealand and India. And

1479.68.text:
President Elect Trump has said Britain is
not “at the back of the queue” for a trade

1483.66.text:
deal with the United States, the world’s
biggest economy, but front of the line.

1489.61.text: I know my emphasis on striking trade agreements with countries outside Europe has led to questions

1495.82.text: about whether Britain seeks to remain a member of the EU’s Customs Union. And it is true

1502.47.text: that full Customs Union membership prevents us from negotiating our own comprehensive

1507.43.text: trade deals. Now, I want Britain to be able to negotiate

1512.07.text:
its own trade agreements. But I also want
tariff-free trade with Europe and cross-border

1518.59.text: trade there to be as frictionless as possible. That means I do not want Britain to be part

1524.90.text: of the Common Commercial Policy and I do not want us to be bound by the Common External

1529.49.text: Tariff. These are the elements of the Customs Union that prevent us from striking our own

1535.09.text: comprehensive trade agreements with other countries. But I do want us to have a customs

1540.90.text: agreement with the EU. Whether that means we must reach a completely

1545.79.text: new customs agreement, become an associate member of the Customs Union in some way, or

1550.95.text:
remain a signatory to some elements of it,
I hold no preconceived position. I have an

1556.22.text: open mind on how we do it. It is not the means that matter, but the ends.

1562.21.text:
And those ends are clear: I want to remove
as many barriers to trade as possible. And

1569.11.text:
I want Britain to be free to establish our
own tariff schedules at the World Trade Organisation,

1574.73.text: meaning we can reach new trade agreements not just with the European Union but with

1579.52.text: old friends and new allies from outside Europe too.

1583.74.text:
A Global Britain must also be a country that
looks to the future. That means being one

1592.00.text:
of the best places in the world for science
and innovation.

1596.29.text:
One of our great strengths as a nation is
the breadth and depth of our academic and

1602.06.text:
scientific communities, backed up by some
of the world’s best universities. And we

1607.62.text: have a proud history of leading and supporting cutting-edge research and innovation.

1613.78.text: So we will also welcome agreement to continue to collaborate with our European partners

1619.45.text:
on major science, research, and technology
initiatives.

1623.86.text:
From space exploration to clean energy to
medical technologies, Britain will remain

1629.18.text:
at the forefront of collective endeavours
to better understand, and make better, the

1634.84.text: world in which we live. And a Global Britain will continue to cooperate

1641.73.text: with its European partners in important areas such as crime, terrorism and foreign affairs.

1652.93.text:
All of us in Europe face the challenge of
cross-border crime, a deadly terrorist threat,

1659.72.text: and the dangers presented by hostile states. All of us share interests and values in common,

1667.72.text:
values we want to see projected around the
world.

1671.84.text: With the threats to our common security becoming more serious, our response cannot be to cooperate

1677.43.text:
with one another less, but to work together
more. I therefore want our future relationship

1684.35.text: with the European Union to include practical arrangements on matters of law enforcement

1689.91.text: and the sharing of intelligence material with our EU allies.

1693.68.text:
I am proud of the role Britain has played
and will continue to play in promoting Europe’s

1699.57.text: security. Britain has led Europe on the measures needed to keep our continent secure – whether

1705.00.text: it is implementing sanctions against Russia following its action in Crimea, working for

1709.98.text: peace and stability in the Balkans, or securing Europe’s external border. We will continue

1716.12.text:
to work closely with our European allies in
foreign and defence policy even as we leave

1722.36.text: the EU itself. These are our objectives for the negotiation

1728.27.text:
ahead – objectives that will help to realise
our ambition of shaping that stronger, fairer,

1735.23.text:
Global Britain that we want to see.
They are the basis for a new, strong, constructive

1740.83.text:
partnership with the European Union – a
partnership of friends and allies, of interests

1746.51.text:
and values. A partnership for a strong EU
and a strong UK.

1753.03.text:
But there is one further objective we are
setting. For as I have said before – it

1758.50.text:
is in no one’s interests for there to be
a cliff-edge for business or a threat to stability,

1764.86.text: as we change from our existing relationship to a new partnership with the EU.

1769.17.text: By this, I do not mean that we will seek some form of unlimited transitional status, in

1775.35.text: which we find ourselves stuck forever in some kind of permanent political purgatory. That

1780.54.text:
would not be good for Britain, but nor do
I believe it would be good for the EU.

1785.19.text: Instead, I want us to have reached an agreement about our future partnership by the time the

1791.29.text: two-year Article Fifty process has concluded. From that point onwards, we believe a phased

1797.51.text: process of implementation, in which both Britain and the EU institutions and member states

1804.37.text:
prepare for the new arrangements that will
exist between us will be in our mutual self-interest.

1810.38.text: This will give businesses enough time to plan and prepare for those new arrangements.

1816.43.text: This might be about our immigration controls, customs systems or the way in which we cooperate

1821.05.text:
on criminal justice matters. Or it might be
about the future legal and regulatory framework

1825.69.text:
for financial services. For each issue, the
time we need to phase-in the new arrangements

1830.86.text:
may differ. Some might be introduced very
quickly, some might take longer. And the interim

1836.72.text:
arrangements we rely upon are likely to be
a matter of negotiation.

1841.51.text:
But the purpose is clear: we will work to
avoid a disruptive cliff-edge, and we will

1847.55.text: do everything we can to phase in the new arrangements we require as Britain and the EU move towards

1854.23.text: our new partnership. So, these are the objectives we have set.

1863.18.text:
Certainty wherever possible. Control of our
own laws. Strengthening the United Kingdom.

1869.20.text: Maintaining the Common Travel Area with Ireland. Control of immigration. Rights for EU nationals

1874.50.text:
in Britain, and British nationals in the EU.
Enhancing rights for workers. Free trade with

1880.15.text: European markets. New trade agreements with other countries. A leading role in science

1885.04.text: and innovation. Cooperation on crime, terrorism and foreign affairs. And a phased approach,

1891.37.text:
delivering a smooth and orderly Brexit.
This is the framework of a deal that will

1897.04.text: herald a new partnership between the UK and the EU.

1901.61.text: It is a comprehensive and carefully considered plan that focuses on the ends, not just the

1908.33.text:
means - with its eyes fixed firmly on the
future, and on the kind of country we will

1914.30.text:
be once we leave.
It reflects the hard work of many in this

1919.42.text: room today who have worked tirelessly to bring it together and to prepare this country for

1924.74.text: the negotiation ahead. And it will, I know, be debated and discussed

1931.18.text:
at length. That is only right. But those who
urge us to reveal more – such as the blow-by-blow

1939.11.text: details of our negotiating strategy, the areas in which we might compromise, the places where

1944.31.text:
we think there are potential trade-offs – will
not be acting in the national interest.

1951.32.text: Because this is not a game or a time for opposition for opposition’s sake. It is a crucial and

1957.79.text:
sensitive negotiation that will define the
interests and the success of our country for

1963.79.text:
many years to come. And it is vital that we
maintain our discipline.

1970.25.text:
That is why I have said before – and will
continue to say – that every stray word

1974.53.text: and every hyped up media report is going to make it harder for us to get the right deal

1979.19.text: for Britain. Our opposite numbers in the European Commission know it, which is why they are

1984.22.text:
keeping their discipline. And the ministers
in this Government know it too, which is why

1988.70.text: we will also maintain ours. So however frustrating some people find it,

1994.80.text:
the Government will not be pressured into
saying more than I believe it is in our national

2000.38.text:
interest to say. Because it is not my job
to fill column inches with daily updates,

2007.53.text:
but to get the right deal for Britain. And
that is what I intend to do.

2013.30.text: I am confident that a deal - and a new strategic partnership between the UK and the EU – can

2020.78.text: be achieved. This is firstly because, having held conversations

2025.64.text:
with almost every leader from every single
EU member state; having spent time talking

2030.94.text: to the senior figures from the European institutions, including President Tusk, President Juncker,

2036.31.text:
and President Schulz; and after my Cabinet
colleagues David Davis, Philip Hammond and

2040.19.text: Boris Johnson have done the same with their interlocutors, I am confident that the vast

2045.42.text: majority want a positive relationship between the UK and the EU after Brexit. And I am confident

2053.43.text:
that the objectives I am setting out today
are consistent with the needs of the EU and

2058.85.text: its Member States. That is why our objectives include a proposed

2064.04.text: Free Trade Agreement between Britain and the European Union, and explicitly rule out membership

2069.45.text:
of the EU’s Single Market. Because when
the EU’s leaders say they believe the four

2075.02.text: freedoms of the Single Market are indivisible, we respect that position. When the 27 Member

2082.09.text: States say they want to continue their journey inside the European Union, we not only respect

2088.36.text: that fact but support it. Because we do not want to undermine the Single

2093.30.text: Market, and we do not want to undermine the European Union. We want the EU to be a success

2101.43.text: and we want its remaining member states to prosper. And of course we want the same for

2107.53.text: Britain. And the second reason I believe it is possible

2111.82.text: to reach a good deal is that the kind of agreement I have described today is the economically

2117.97.text:
rational thing that both Britain and the EU
should aim for. Because trade is not a zero

2125.44.text: sum game: more of it makes us all more prosperous. Free trade between Britain and the European

2132.82.text: Union means more trade, and more trade means more jobs and more wealth creation. The erection

2139.01.text:
of new barriers to trade, meanwhile, means
the reverse: less trade, fewer jobs, lower

2146.00.text: growth. The third and final reason I believe we can

2149.39.text: come to the right agreement is that cooperation between Britain and the EU is needed not just

2156.24.text: when it comes to trade but when it comes to our security too.

2161.50.text:
Britain and France are Europe’s only two
nuclear powers. We are the only two European

2166.64.text: countries with permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council. Britain’s armed

2171.52.text: forces are a crucial part of Europe’s collective defence.

2176.14.text:
And our intelligence capabilities – unique
in Europe – have already saved countless

2180.16.text:
lives in very many terrorist plots that have
been thwarted in countries across our continent.

2185.46.text: After Brexit, Britain wants to be a good friend and neighbour in every way, and that includes

2192.00.text:
defending the safety and security of all of
our citizens.

2196.80.text:
So I believe the framework I have outlined
today is in Britain’s interests. It is

2201.43.text:
in Europe’s interests. And it is in the
interests of the wider world.

2206.49.text:
But I must be clear. Britain wants to remain
a good friend and neighbour to Europe. Yet

2214.17.text:
I know there are some voices calling for a
punitive deal that punishes Britain and discourages

2220.01.text:
other countries from taking the same path.
That would be an act of calamitous self-harm

2226.61.text:
for the countries of Europe. And it would
not be the act of a friend.

2232.00.text:
Britain would not – indeed we could not
– accept such an approach. And while I am

2237.94.text: confident that this scenario need never arise – while I am sure a positive agreement can

2243.99.text:
be reached – I am equally clear that no
deal for Britain is better than a bad deal

2250.03.text: for Britain. Because we would still be able to trade with

2254.14.text: Europe. We would be free to strike trade deals across the world. And we would have the freedom

2260.00.text: to set the competitive tax rates and embrace the policies that would attract the world’s

2264.90.text: best companies and biggest investors to Britain. And – if we were excluded from accessing

2270.28.text:
the Single Market – we would be free to
change the basis of Britain’s economic model.

2276.75.text:
But for the EU, it would mean new barriers
to trade with one of the biggest economies

2281.39.text: in the world. It would jeopardise investments in Britain by EU companies worth more than

2286.73.text:
half a trillion pounds. It would mean a loss
of access for European firms to the financial

2292.54.text:
services of the City of London. It would risk
exports from the EU to Britain worth around

2297.39.text:
£290 billion every year. And it would disrupt
the sophisticated and integrated supply chains

2305.72.text:
upon which many EU companies rely.
Important sectors of the EU economy would

2311.25.text:
also suffer. We are a crucial – profitable
– export market for Europe’s automotive

2316.56.text: industry, as well as sectors including energy, food and drink, chemicals, pharmaceuticals,

2321.34.text: and agriculture. These sectors employ millions of people around Europe. And I do not believe

2326.91.text:
that the EU’s leaders will seriously tell
German exporters, French farmers, Spanish

2332.03.text: fishermen, the young unemployed of the Eurozone, and millions of others, that they want to

2336.69.text: make them poorer, just to punish Britain and make a political point.

2340.74.text:
For all these reasons – and because of our
shared values and the spirit of goodwill that

2346.97.text:
exists on both sides – I am confident that
we will follow a better path. I am confident

2353.19.text:
that a positive agreement can be reached.
It is right that the Government should prepare

2358.51.text:
for every eventuality - but to do so in the
knowledge that a constructive and optimistic

2363.74.text:
approach to the negotiations to come is in
the best interests of Europe and the best

2368.06.text: interests of Britain. We do not approach these negotiations expecting

2376.89.text:
Because we are a great, global nation with
so much to offer Europe and so much to offer the world.

2383.33.text:
One of the world’s largest and strongest
economies. With the finest intelligence services,

2388.07.text: the bravest armed forces, the most effective hard and soft power, and friendships, partnerships

2397.42.text:
And another thing that’s important. The
essential ingredient of our success. The strength

2403.60.text:
and support of 65 million people willing us
to make it happen.

2409.72.text:
Because after all the division and discord,
the country is coming together.

2415.54.text:
The referendum was divisive at times. And
those divisions have taken time to heal.

2421.95.text: But one of the reasons that Britain’s democracy has been such a success for so many years

2427.23.text:
is that the strength of our identity as one
nation, the respect we show to one another

2432.46.text:
as fellow citizens, and the importance we
attach to our institutions means that when

2438.36.text: a vote has been held we all respect the result. The victors have the responsibility to act

2445.49.text: magnanimously. The losers have the responsibility to respect the legitimacy of the outcome.

2455.42.text: And that is what we are seeing today. Business isn’t calling to reverse the result, but

2461.29.text: planning to make a success of it. The House of Commons has voted overwhelmingly for us

2466.54.text: to get on with it. And the overwhelming majority of people – however they voted – want

2471.70.text: us to get on with it too.

2474.39.text: So that is what we will do.

2476.10.text: Not merely forming a new partnership with Europe, but building a stronger, fairer, more Global Britain too.

2485.55.text:
And let that be the legacy of our time. The
prize towards which we work. The destination

2492.39.text:
at which we arrive once the negotiation is
done.

2495.67.text: And let us do it not for ourselves, but for those who follow. For the country’s children and grandchildren too.

2505.07.text:
So that when future generations look back
at this time, they will judge us not only

2509.99.text:
by the decision that we made, but by what
we made of that decision.

2516.29.text: They will see that we shaped them a brighter future.

2520.26.text:
They will know that we built them a better
Britain.
